text: The descendants of Adam were Seth, Enosh,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared,
speaker: Narrator

text: Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and Noah.
The sons of Noah were Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Japheth were Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Gomer were Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Javan were Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Ham were Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Cush were Seba, Havilah, Sabtah, Raamah, and Sabteca. The descendants of Raamah were Sheba and Dedan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cush was also the ancestor of Nimrod, who was the first heroic warrior on earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mizraim was the ancestor of the Ludites, Anamites, Lehabites, Naphtuhites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Pathrusites, Casluhites, and the Caphtorites, from whom the Philistines came.
speaker: Narrator

text: Canaan’s oldest son was Sidon, the ancestor of the Sidonians. Canaan was also the ancestor of the Hittites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jebusites, Amorites, Girgashites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hivites, Arkites, Sinites,
speaker: Narrator

text: Arvadites, Zemarites, and Hamathites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The descendants of Shem were Elam, Asshur, Arphaxad, Lud, and Aram.
The descendants of Aram were Uz, Hul, Gether, and Mash.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Arphaxad was the father of Shelah.
Shelah was the father of Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eber had two sons. The first was named Peleg (which means “division”), for during his lifetime the people of the world were divided into different language groups. His brother’s name was Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joktan was the ancestor of Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Obal, Abimael, Sheba,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All these were descendants of Joktan.
speaker: Narrator

text: So this is the family line descended from Shem: Arphaxad, Shelah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eber, Peleg, Reu,
speaker: Narrator

text: Serug, Nahor, Terah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Abram, later known as Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Abraham were Isaac and Ishmael.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are their genealogical records:
The sons of Ishmael were Nebaioth (the oldest), Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah. These were the sons of Ishmael.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Keturah, Abraham’s concubine, were Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah.
The sons of Jokshan were Sheba and Dedan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Midian were Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah.
All these were descendants of Abraham through his concubine Keturah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abraham was the father of Isaac. The sons of Isaac were Esau and Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Esau were Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, Gatam, Kenaz, and Amalek, who was born to Timna.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Reuel were Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Seir were Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Lotan were Hori and Hemam. Lotan’s sister was named Timna.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The descendants of Shobal were Alvan, Manahath, Ebal, Shepho, and Onam.
The descendants of Zibeon were Aiah and Anah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The son of Anah was Dishon.
The descendants of Dishon were Hemdan, Eshban, Ithran, and Keran.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The descendants of Ezer were Bilhan, Zaavan, and Akan.
The descendants of Dishan were Uz and Aran.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the kings who ruled in the land of Edom before any king ruled over the Israelites:
Bela son of Beor, who ruled from his city of Dinhabah.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Bela died, Jobab son of Zerah from Bozrah became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Jobab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Husham died, Hadad son of Bedad became king in his place and ruled from the city of Avith. He was the one who destroyed the Midianite army in the land of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hadad died, Samlah from the city of Masrekah became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Samlah died, Shaul from the city of Rehoboth-on-the-River became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Shaul died, Baal-hanan son of Acbor became king in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Baal-hanan died, Hadad became king in his place and ruled from the city of Pau. His wife was Mehetabel, the daughter of Matred and granddaughter of Me-zahab.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Hadad died.
The clan leaders of Edom were Timna, Alvah, Jetheth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar,
speaker: Narrator

text: Magdiel, and Iram. These are the clan leaders of Edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Israel were Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun,
speaker: Narrator

text: Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah had three sons from Bathshua, a Canaanite woman. Their names were Er, Onan, and Shelah. But the Lord saw that the oldest son, Er, was a wicked man, so he killed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Later Judah had twin sons from Tamar, his widowed daughter-in-law. Their names were Perez and Zerah. So Judah had five sons in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Zerah were Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Darda—five in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Carmi (a descendant of Zimri) was Achan, who brought disaster on Israel by taking plunder that had been set apart for the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Ethan was Azariah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Hezron were Jerahmeel, Ram, and Caleb.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ram was the father of Amminadab.
Amminadab was the father of Nahshon, a leader of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nahshon was the father of Salmon.
Salmon was the father of Boaz.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Boaz was the father of Obed.
Obed was the father of Jesse.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jesse’s first son was Eliab, his second was Abinadab, his third was Shimea,
speaker: Narrator

text: his fourth was Nethanel, his fifth was Raddai,
speaker: Narrator

text: his sixth was Ozem, and his seventh was David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their sisters were named Zeruiah and Abigail. Zeruiah had three sons named Abishai, Joab, and Asahel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abigail married a man named Jether, an Ishmaelite, and they had a son named Amasa.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hezron’s son Caleb had sons from his wife Azubah and from Jerioth. Her sons were named Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Azubah died, Caleb married Ephrathah, and they had a son named Hur.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hur was the father of Uri. Uri was the father of Bezalel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hezron was sixty years old, he married Gilead’s sister, the daughter of Makir. They had a son named Segub.
speaker: Narrator

text: Segub was the father of Jair, who ruled twenty-three towns in the land of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: (But Geshur and Aram captured the Towns of Jair and also took Kenath and its sixty surrounding villages.) All these were descendants of Makir, the father of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Soon after Hezron died in the town of Caleb-ephrathah, his wife Abijah gave birth to a son named Ashhur (the father of Tekoa).
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jerahmeel, the oldest son of Hezron, were Ram (the firstborn), Bunah, Oren, Ozem, and Ahijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jerahmeel had a second wife named Atarah. She was the mother of Onam.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Ram, the oldest son of Jerahmeel, were Maaz, Jamin, and Eker.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Onam were Shammai and Jada.
The sons of Shammai were Nadab and Abishur.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Abishur and his wife Abihail were Ahban and Molid.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Nadab were Seled and Appaim. Seled died without children,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Appaim had a son named Ishi. The son of Ishi was Sheshan. Sheshan had a descendant named Ahlai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jada, Shammai’s brother, were Jether and Jonathan. Jether died without children,
speaker: Narrator

text:
but Jonathan had two sons named Peleth and Zaza.
These were all descendants of Jerahmeel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sheshan had no sons, though he did have daughters. He also had an Egyptian servant named Jarha.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sheshan gave one of his daughters to be the wife of Jarha, and they had a son named Attai.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Attai was the father of Nathan.
Nathan was the father of Zabad.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zabad was the father of Ephlal.
Ephlal was the father of Obed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Obed was the father of Jehu.
Jehu was the father of Azariah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Azariah was the father of Helez.
Helez was the father of Eleasah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eleasah was the father of Sismai.
Sismai was the father of Shallum.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shallum was the father of Jekamiah.
Jekamiah was the father of Elishama.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Caleb, the brother of Jerahmeel, included Mesha (the firstborn), who became the father of Ziph. Caleb’s descendants also included the sons of Mareshah, the father of Hebron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Hebron were Korah, Tappuah, Rekem, and Shema.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shema was the father of Raham. Raham was the father of Jorkeam. Rekem was the father of Shammai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Shammai was Maon. Maon was the father of Beth-zur.
speaker: Narrator

text: Caleb’s concubine Ephah gave birth to Haran, Moza, and Gazez. Haran was the father of Gazez.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jahdai were Regem, Jotham, Geshan, Pelet, Ephah, and Shaaph.
speaker: Narrator

text: Another of Caleb’s concubines, Maacah, gave birth to Sheber and Tirhanah.
speaker: Narrator

text: She also gave birth to Shaaph (the father of Madmannah) and Sheva (the father of Macbenah and Gibea). Caleb also had a daughter named Acsah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were all descendants of Caleb.
The sons of Hur, the oldest son of Caleb’s wife Ephrathah, were Shobal (the founder of Kiriath-jearim),
speaker: Narrator

text: Salma (the founder of Bethlehem), and Hareph (the founder of Beth-gader).
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Shobal (the founder of Kiriath-jearim) were Haroeh, half the Manahathites,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the families of Kiriath-jearim—the Ithrites, Puthites, Shumathites, and Mishraites, from whom came the people of Zorah and Eshtaol.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Salma were the people of Bethlehem, the Netophathites, Atroth-beth-joab, the other half of the Manahathites, the Zorites,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the families of scribes living at Jabez—the Tirathites, Shimeathites, and Sucathites. All these were Kenites who descended from Hammath, the father of the family of Recab.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the sons of David who were born in Hebron:
The oldest was Amnon, whose mother was Ahinoam from Jezreel.
The second was Daniel, whose mother was Abigail from Carmel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The third was Absalom, whose mother was Maacah, the daughter of Talmai, king of Geshur.
The fourth was Adonijah, whose mother was Haggith.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fifth was Shephatiah, whose mother was Abital.
The sixth was Ithream, whose mother was Eglah, David’s wife.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These six sons were born to David in Hebron, where he reigned seven and a half years.
Then David reigned another thirty-three years in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons born to David in Jerusalem included Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon. Their mother was Bathsheba, the daughter of Ammiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also had nine other sons: Ibhar, Elishua, Elpelet,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the sons of David, not including his sons born to his concubines. Their sister was named Tamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Solomon were Rehoboam, Abijah, Asa, Jehoshaphat,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jehoram, Ahaziah, Joash,
speaker: Narrator

text: Amaziah, Uzziah, Jotham,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahaz, Hezekiah, Manasseh,
speaker: Narrator

text: Amon, and Josiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Josiah were Johanan (the oldest), Jehoiakim (the second), Zedekiah (the third), and Jehoahaz (the fourth).
speaker: Narrator

text: The successors of Jehoiakim were his son Jehoiachin and his brother Zedekiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jehoiachin, who was taken prisoner by the Babylonians, were Shealtiel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Malkiram, Pedaiah, Shenazzar, Jekamiah, Hoshama, and Nedabiah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Pedaiah were Zerubbabel and Shimei.
The sons of Zerubbabel were Meshullam and Hananiah. (Their sister was Shelomith.)
speaker: Narrator

text: His five other sons were Hashubah, Ohel, Berekiah, Hasadiah, and Jushab-hesed.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Hananiah were Pelatiah and Jeshaiah. Jeshaiah’s son was Rephaiah. Rephaiah’s son was Arnan. Arnan’s son was Obadiah. Obadiah’s son was Shecaniah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Shecaniah were Shemaiah and his sons, Hattush, Igal, Bariah, Neariah, and Shaphat—six in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Neariah were Elioenai, Hizkiah, and Azrikam—three in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Elioenai were Hodaviah, Eliashib, Pelaiah, Akkub, Johanan, Delaiah, and Anani—seven in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Judah were Perez, Hezron, Carmi, Hur, and Shobal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shobal’s son Reaiah was the father of Jahath. Jahath was the father of Ahumai and Lahad. These were the families of the Zorathites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Etam were Jezreel, Ishma, Idbash, their sister Hazzelelponi,
speaker: Narrator

text: Penuel (the father of Gedor), and Ezer (the father of Hushah). These were the descendants of Hur (the firstborn of Ephrathah), the ancestor of Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ashhur (the father of Tekoa) had two wives, named Helah and Naarah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Naarah gave birth to Ahuzzam, Hepher, Temeni, and Haahashtari.
speaker: Narrator

text: Helah gave birth to Zereth, Izhar, Ethnan,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Koz, who became the ancestor of Anub, Zobebah, and all the families of Aharhel son of Harum.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was a man named Jabez who was more honorable than any of his brothers. His mother named him Jabez because his birth had been so painful.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was the one who prayed to the God of Israel, “Oh, that you would bless me and expand my territory! Please be with me in all that I do, and keep me from all trouble and pain!” And God granted him his request.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kelub (the brother of Shuhah) was the father of Mehir. Mehir was the father of Eshton.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eshton was the father of Beth-rapha, Paseah, and Tehinnah. Tehinnah was the father of Ir-nahash. These were the descendants of Recah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Kenaz were Othniel and Seraiah. Othniel’s sons were Hathath and Meonothai.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meonothai was the father of Ophrah. Seraiah was the father of Joab, the founder of the Valley of Craftsmen, so called because they were craftsmen.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Caleb son of Jephunneh were Iru, Elah, and Naam. The son of Elah was Kenaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jehallelel were Ziph, Ziphah, Tiria, and Asarel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Ezrah were Jether, Mered, Epher, and Jalon. One of Mered’s wives became the mother of Miriam, Shammai, and Ishbah (the father of Eshtemoa).
speaker: Narrator

text: He married a woman from Judah, who became the mother of Jered (the father of Gedor), Heber (the father of Soco), and Jekuthiel (the father of Zanoah). Mered also married Bithia, a daughter of Pharaoh, and she bore him children.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hodiah’s wife was the sister of Naham. One of her sons was the father of Keilah the Garmite, and another was the father of Eshtemoa the Maacathite.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sons of Shimon were Amnon, Rinnah, Ben-hanan, and Tilon.
The descendants of Ishi were Zoheth and Ben-zoheth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelah was one of Judah’s sons. The descendants of Shelah were Er (the father of Lecah); Laadah (the father of Mareshah); the families of linen workers at Beth-ashbea;
speaker: Narrator

text: Jokim; the men of Cozeba; and Joash and Saraph, who ruled over Moab and Jashubi-lehem. These names all come from ancient records.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were the pottery makers who lived in Netaim and Gederah. They lived there and worked for the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Jarib, Zohar, and Shaul.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Shaul were Shallum, Mibsam, and Mishma.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Mishma were Hammuel, Zaccur, and Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimei had sixteen sons and six daughters, but none of his brothers had large families. So Simeon’s tribe never grew as large as the tribe of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They lived in Beersheba, Moladah, Hazar-shual,
speaker: Narrator

text: Bilhah, Ezem, Tolad,
speaker: Narrator

text: Bethuel, Hormah, Ziklag,
speaker: Narrator

text: Beth-marcaboth, Hazar-susim, Beth-biri, and Shaaraim. These towns were under their control until the time of King David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their descendants also lived in Etam, Ain, Rimmon, Token, and Ashan—five towns
speaker: Narrator

text: and their surrounding villages as far away as Baalath. This was their territory, and these names are listed in their genealogical records.
speaker: Narrator

text: Other descendants of Simeon included Meshobab, Jamlech, Joshah son of Amaziah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Joel, Jehu son of Joshibiah, son of Seraiah, son of Asiel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Ziza son of Shiphi, son of Allon, son of Jedaiah, son of Shimri, son of Shemaiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the names of some of the leaders of Simeon’s wealthy clans. Their families grew,
speaker: Narrator

text: and they traveled to the region of Gerar, in the east part of the valley, seeking pastureland for their flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They found lush pastures there, and the land was spacious, quiet, and peaceful.
Some of Ham’s descendants had been living in that region.
speaker: Narrator

text: But during the reign of King Hezekiah of Judah, these leaders of Simeon invaded the region and completely destroyed the homes of the descendants of Ham and of the Meunites. No trace of them remains today. They killed everyone who lived there and took the land for themselves, because they wanted its good pastureland for their flocks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Five hundred of these invaders from the tribe of Simeon went to Mount Seir, led by Pelatiah, Neariah, Rephaiah, and Uzziel—all sons of Ishi.
speaker: Narrator

text: They destroyed the few Amalekites who had survived, and they have lived there ever since.
speaker: Narrator

text: The oldest son of Israel was Reuben. But since he dishonored his father by sleeping with one of his father’s concubines, his birthright was given to the sons of his brother Joseph. For this reason, Reuben is not listed in the genealogical records as the firstborn son.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Judah became the most powerful tribe and provided a ruler for the nation, but the birthright belonged to Joseph.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Reuben, the oldest son of Israel, were Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Joel were Shemaiah, Gog, Shimei,
speaker: Narrator

text: Micah, Reaiah, Baal,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Beerah. Beerah was the leader of the Reubenites when they were taken into captivity by King Tiglath-pileser of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: Beerah’s relatives are listed in their genealogical records by their clans: Jeiel (the leader), Zechariah,
speaker: Narrator

text:
and Bela son of Azaz, son of Shema, son of Joel.
The Reubenites lived in the area that stretches from Aroer to Nebo and Baal-meon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And since they had so many livestock in the land of Gilead, they spread east toward the edge of the desert that stretches to the Euphrates River.
speaker: Narrator

text: During the reign of Saul, the Reubenites defeated the Hagrites in battle. Then they moved into the Hagrite settlements all along the eastern edge of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next to the Reubenites, the descendants of Gad lived in the land of Bashan as far east as Salecah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joel was the leader in the land of Bashan, and Shapham was second-in-command, followed by Janai and Shaphat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their relatives, the leaders of seven other clans, were Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Eber.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were all descendants of Abihail son of Huri, son of Jaroah, son of Gilead, son of Michael, son of Jeshishai, son of Jahdo, son of Buz.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahi son of Abdiel, son of Guni, was the leader of their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gadites lived in the land of Gilead, in Bashan and its villages, and throughout all the pasturelands of Sharon.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these were listed in the genealogical records during the days of King Jotham of Judah and King Jeroboam of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were 44,760 capable warriors in the armies of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh. They were all skilled in combat and armed with shields, swords, and bows.
speaker: Narrator

text: They waged war against the Hagrites, the Jeturites, the Naphishites, and the Nodabites.
speaker: Narrator

text: They cried out to God during the battle, and he answered their prayer because they trusted in him. So the Hagrites and all their allies were defeated.
speaker: Narrator

text: The plunder taken from the Hagrites included 50,000 camels, 250,000 sheep and goats, 2,000 donkeys, and 100,000 captives.
speaker: Narrator

text: Many of the Hagrites were killed in the battle because God was fighting against them. The people of Reuben, Gad, and Manasseh lived in their land until they were taken into exile.
speaker: Narrator

text: The half-tribe of Manasseh was very large and spread through the land from Bashan to Baal-hermon, Senir, and Mount Hermon.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the leaders of their clans: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel. These men had a great reputation as mighty warriors and leaders of their clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: But these tribes were unfaithful to the God of their ancestors. They worshiped the gods of the nations that God had destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the God of Israel caused King Pul of Assyria (also known as Tiglath-pileser) to invade the land and take away the people of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh as captives. The Assyrians exiled them to Halah, Habor, Hara, and the Gozan River, where they remain to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Kohath included Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The children of Amram were Aaron, Moses, and Miriam.
The sons of Aaron were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eleazar was the father of Phinehas.
Phinehas was the father of Abishua.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Abishua was the father of Bukki.
Bukki was the father of Uzzi.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Uzzi was the father of Zerahiah.
Zerahiah was the father of Meraioth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Meraioth was the father of Amariah.
Amariah was the father of Ahitub.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahitub was the father of Zadok.
Zadok was the father of Ahimaaz.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahimaaz was the father of Azariah.
Azariah was the father of Johanan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Johanan was the father of Azariah, the high priest at the Temple built by Solomon in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Azariah was the father of Amariah.
Amariah was the father of Ahitub.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahitub was the father of Zadok.
Zadok was the father of Shallum.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shallum was the father of Hilkiah.
Hilkiah was the father of Azariah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Azariah was the father of Seraiah.
Seraiah was the father of Jehozadak,
speaker: Narrator

text: who went into exile when the Lord sent the people of Judah and Jerusalem into captivity under Nebuchadnezzar.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Levi were Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Gershon included Libni and Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Kohath included Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The descendants of Merari included Mahli and Mushi.
The following were the Levite clans, listed according to their ancestral descent:
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Gershon included Libni, Jahath, Zimmah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Joah, Iddo, Zerah, and Jeatherai.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Kohath included Amminadab, Korah, Assir,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elkanah, Abiasaph, Assir,
speaker: Narrator

text: Tahath, Uriel, Uzziah, and Shaul.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Elkanah included Amasai, Ahimoth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elkanah, Zophai, Nahath,
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliab, Jeroham, Elkanah, and Samuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Samuel were Joel (the older) and Abijah (the second).
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Merari included Mahli, Libni, Shimei, Uzzah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shimea, Haggiah, and Asaiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: David assigned the following men to lead the music at the house of the Lord after the Ark was placed there.
speaker: Narrator

text: They ministered with music at the Tabernacle until Solomon built the Temple of the Lord in Jerusalem. They carried out their work, following all the regulations handed down to them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the men who served, along with their sons:
Heman the musician was from the clan of Kohath. His genealogy was traced back through Joel, Samuel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elkanah, Jeroham, Eliel, Toah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zuph, Elkanah, Mahath, Amasai,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elkanah, Joel, Azariah, Zephaniah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Tahath, Assir, Abiasaph, Korah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Izhar, Kohath, Levi, and Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heman’s first assistant was Asaph from the clan of Gershon. Asaph’s genealogy was traced back through Berekiah, Shimea,
speaker: Narrator

text: Michael, Baaseiah, Malkijah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ethni, Zerah, Adaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ethan, Zimmah, Shimei,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jahath, Gershon, and Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heman’s second assistant was Ethan from the clan of Merari. Ethan’s genealogy was traced back through Kishi, Abdi, Malluch,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hashabiah, Amaziah, Hilkiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Amzi, Bani, Shemer,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mahli, Mushi, Merari, and Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their fellow Levites were appointed to various other tasks in the Tabernacle, the house of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Only Aaron and his descendants served as priests. They presented the offerings on the altar of burnt offering and the altar of incense, and they performed all the other duties related to the Most Holy Place. They made atonement for Israel by doing everything that Moses, the servant of God, had commanded them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Aaron were Eleazar, Phinehas, Abishua,
speaker: Narrator

text: Bukki, Uzzi, Zerahiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Meraioth, Amariah, Ahitub,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zadok, and Ahimaaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is a record of the towns and territory assigned by means of sacred lots to the descendants of Aaron, who were from the clan of Kohath.
speaker: Narrator

text: This territory included Hebron and its surrounding pasturelands in Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: but the fields and outlying areas belonging to the city were given to Caleb son of Jephunneh.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the descendants of Aaron were given the following towns, each with its pasturelands: Hebron (a city of refuge), Libnah, Jattir, Eshtemoa,
speaker: Narrator

text: Holon, Debir,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ain, Juttah, and Beth-shemesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from the territory of Benjamin they were given Gibeon, Geba, Alemeth, and Anathoth, each with its pasturelands. So thirteen towns were given to the descendants of Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The remaining descendants of Kohath received ten towns from the territory of the half-tribe of Manasseh by means of sacred lots.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Gershon received by sacred lots thirteen towns from the territories of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and from the Bashan area of Manasseh, east of the Jordan.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Merari received by sacred lots twelve towns from the territories of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people of Israel assigned all these towns and pasturelands to the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The towns in the territories of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin, mentioned above, were assigned to them by means of sacred lots.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Kohath were given the following towns from the territory of Ephraim, each with its pasturelands:
speaker: Narrator

text: Shechem (a city of refuge in the hill country of Ephraim), Gezer,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jokmeam, Beth-horon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Aijalon, and Gath-rimmon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The remaining descendants of Kohath were assigned the towns of Aner and Bileam from the territory of the half-tribe of Manasseh, each with its pasturelands.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Gershon received the towns of Golan (in Bashan) and Ashtaroth from the territory of the half-tribe of Manasseh, each with its pasturelands.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the territory of Issachar, they were given Kedesh, Daberath,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ramoth, and Anem, each with its pasturelands.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the territory of Asher, they received Mashal, Abdon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hukok, and Rehob, each with its pasturelands.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the territory of Naphtali, they were given Kedesh in Galilee, Hammon, and Kiriathaim, each with its pasturelands.
speaker: Narrator

text: The remaining descendants of Merari received the towns of Jokneam, Kartah, Rimmon, and Tabor from the territory of Zebulun, each with its pasturelands.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the territory of Reuben, east of the Jordan River opposite Jericho, they received Bezer (a desert town), Jahaz,
speaker: Narrator

text: Kedemoth, and Mephaath, each with its pasturelands.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from the territory of Gad, they received Ramoth in Gilead, Mahanaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: Heshbon, and Jazer, each with its pasturelands.
speaker: Narrator

text: The four sons of Issachar were Tola, Puah, Jashub, and Shimron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Tola were Uzzi, Rephaiah, Jeriel, Jahmai, Ibsam, and Shemuel. Each of them was the leader of an ancestral clan. At the time of King David, the total number of mighty warriors listed in the records of these clans was 22,600.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Uzzi was Izrahiah. The sons of Izrahiah were Michael, Obadiah, Joel, and Isshiah. These five became the leaders of clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of them had many wives and many sons, so the total number of men available for military service among their descendants was 36,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: The total number of mighty warriors from all the clans of the tribe of Issachar was 87,000. All of them were listed in their genealogical records.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three of Benjamin’s sons were Bela, Beker, and Jediael.
speaker: Narrator

text: The five sons of Bela were Ezbon, Uzzi, Uzziel, Jerimoth, and Iri. Each of them was the leader of an ancestral clan. The total number of mighty warriors from these clans was 22,034, as listed in their genealogical records.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Beker were Zemirah, Joash, Eliezer, Elioenai, Omri, Jeremoth, Abijah, Anathoth, and Alemeth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of them was the leader of an ancestral clan. The total number of mighty warriors and leaders from these clans was 20,200, as listed in their genealogical records.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Jediael was Bilhan. The sons of Bilhan were Jeush, Benjamin, Ehud, Kenaanah, Zethan, Tarshish, and Ahishahar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of them was the leader of an ancestral clan. From these clans the total number of mighty warriors ready for war was 17,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Ir were Shuppim and Huppim. Hushim was the son of Aher.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Naphtali were Jahzeel, Guni, Jezer, and Shillem. They were all descendants of Jacob’s concubine Bilhah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Manasseh through his Aramean concubine included Asriel. She also bore Makir, the father of Gilead.
speaker: Narrator

text: Makir found wives for Huppim and Shuppim. Makir had a sister named Maacah. One of his descendants was Zelophehad, who had only daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Makir’s wife, Maacah, gave birth to a son whom she named Peresh. His brother’s name was Sheresh. The sons of Peresh were Ulam and Rakem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The son of Ulam was Bedan. All these were considered Gileadites, descendants of Makir son of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: Makir’s sister Hammoleketh gave birth to Ishhod, Abiezer, and Mahlah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Shemida were Ahian, Shechem, Likhi, and Aniam.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Ephraim were Shuthelah, Bered, Tahath, Eleadah, Tahath,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zabad, Shuthelah, Ezer, and Elead. These two were killed trying to steal livestock from the local farmers near Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their father, Ephraim, mourned for them a long time, and his relatives came to comfort him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Afterward Ephraim slept with his wife, and she became pregnant and gave birth to a son. Ephraim named him Beriah because of the tragedy his family had suffered.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had a daughter named Sheerah. She built the towns of Lower and Upper Beth-horon and Uzzen-sheerah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Ephraim included Rephah, Resheph, Telah, Tahan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ladan, Ammihud, Elishama,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nun, and Joshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Ephraim lived in the territory that included Bethel and its surrounding towns to the south, Naaran to the east, Gezer and its villages to the west, and Shechem and its surrounding villages to the north as far as Ayyah and its towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: Along the border of Manasseh were the towns of Beth-shan, Taanach, Megiddo, Dor, and their surrounding villages. The descendants of Joseph son of Israel lived in these towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Asher were Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, and Beriah. They had a sister named Serah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Beriah were Heber and Malkiel (the father of Birzaith).
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Heber were Japhlet, Shomer, and Hotham. They had a sister named Shua.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Japhlet were Pasach, Bimhal, and Ashvath.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Shomer were Ahi, Rohgah, Hubbah, and Aram.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of his brother Helem were Zophah, Imna, Shelesh, and Amal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Zophah were Suah, Harnepher, Shual, Beri, Imrah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Bezer, Hod, Shamma, Shilshah, Ithran, and Beera.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jether were Jephunneh, Pispah, and Ara.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Ulla were Arah, Hanniel, and Rizia.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each of these descendants of Asher was the head of an ancestral clan. They were all select men—mighty warriors and outstanding leaders. The total number of men available for military service was 26,000, as listed in their genealogical records.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benjamin’s first son was Bela, the second was Ashbel, the third was Aharah,
speaker: Narrator

text: the fourth was Nohah, and the fifth was Rapha.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Bela were Addar, Gera, Abihud,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishua, Naaman, Ahoah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gera, Shephuphan, and Huram.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Ehud, leaders of the clans living at Geba, were exiled to Manahath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ehud’s sons were Naaman, Ahijah, and Gera. Gera, who led them into exile, was the father of Uzza and Ahihud.
speaker: Narrator

text: After Shaharaim divorced his wives Hushim and Baara, he had children in the land of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: His wife Hodesh gave birth to Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeuz, Sakia, and Mirmah. These sons all became the leaders of clans.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shaharaim’s wife Hushim had already given birth to Abitub and Elpaal.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Elpaal were Eber, Misham, Shemed (who built the towns of Ono and Lod and their nearby villages),
speaker: Narrator

text: Beriah, and Shema. They were the leaders of the clans living in Aijalon, and they drove out the inhabitants of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahio, Shashak, Jeremoth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zebadiah, Arad, Eder,
speaker: Narrator

text: Michael, Ishpah, and Joha were the sons of Beriah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zebadiah, Meshullam, Hizki, Heber,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishmerai, Izliah, and Jobab were the sons of Elpaal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jakim, Zicri, Zabdi,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elienai, Zillethai, Eliel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Adaiah, Beraiah, and Shimrath were the sons of Shimei.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ishpan, Eber, Eliel,
speaker: Narrator

text: Abdon, Zicri, Hanan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hananiah, Elam, Anthothijah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Iphdeiah, and Penuel were the sons of Shashak.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shamsherai, Shehariah, Athaliah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Jaareshiah, Elijah, and Zicri were the sons of Jeroham.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the leaders of the ancestral clans; they were listed in their genealogical records, and they all lived in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeiel (the father of Gibeon) lived in the town of Gibeon. His wife’s name was Maacah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and his oldest son was named Abdon. Jeiel’s other sons were Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and Mikloth, who was the father of Shimeam. All these families lived near each other in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ner was the father of Kish.
Kish was the father of Saul.
Saul was the father of Jonathan, Malkishua, Abinadab, and Esh-baal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jonathan was the father of Merib-baal.
Merib-baal was the father of Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Micah was the father of Pithon, Melech, Tahrea, and Ahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahaz was the father of Jadah.
Jadah was the father of Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri.
Zimri was the father of Moza.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moza was the father of Binea.
Binea was the father of Rephaiah.
Rephaiah was the father of Eleasah.
Eleasah was the father of Azel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Azel had six sons: Azrikam, Bokeru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. These were the sons of Azel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Azel’s brother Eshek had three sons: the first was Ulam, the second was Jeush, and the third was Eliphelet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ulam’s sons were all mighty warriors and expert archers. They had many sons and grandsons—150 in all.
All these were descendants of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So all Israel was listed in the genealogical records in The Book of the Kings of Israel.
The people of Judah were exiled to Babylon because they were unfaithful to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first of the exiles to return to their property in their former towns were priests, Levites, Temple servants, and other Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the people from the tribes of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh came and settled in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: One family that returned was that of Uthai son of Ammihud, son of Omri, son of Imri, son of Bani, a descendant of Perez son of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Others returned from the Shilonite clan, including Asaiah (the oldest) and his sons.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the Zerahite clan, Jeuel returned with his relatives.
In all, 690 families from the tribe of Judah returned.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Benjamin came Sallu son of Meshullam, son of Hodaviah, son of Hassenuah;
speaker: Narrator

text: Ibneiah son of Jeroham; Elah son of Uzzi, son of Micri; and Meshullam son of Shephatiah, son of Reuel, son of Ibnijah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These men were all leaders of clans, and they were listed in their genealogical records. In all, 956 families from the tribe of Benjamin returned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Among the priests who returned were Jedaiah, Jehoiarib, Jakin,
speaker: Narrator

text: Azariah son of Hilkiah, son of Meshullam, son of Zadok, son of Meraioth, son of Ahitub. Azariah was the chief officer of the house of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Other returning priests were Adaiah son of Jeroham, son of Pashhur, son of Malkijah, and Maasai son of Adiel, son of Jahzerah, son of Meshullam, son of Meshillemith, son of Immer.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all, 1,760 priests returned. They were heads of clans and very able men. They were responsible for ministering at the house of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites who returned were Shemaiah son of Hasshub, son of Azrikam, son of Hashabiah, a descendant of Merari;
speaker: Narrator

text: Bakbakkar; Heresh; Galal; Mattaniah son of Mica, son of Zicri, son of Asaph;
speaker: Narrator

text: Obadiah son of Shemaiah, son of Galal, son of Jeduthun; and Berekiah son of Asa, son of Elkanah, who lived in the area of Netophah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gatekeepers who returned were Shallum, Akkub, Talmon, Ahiman, and their relatives. Shallum was the chief gatekeeper.
speaker: Narrator

text: Prior to this time, they were responsible for the King’s Gate on the east side. These men served as gatekeepers for the camps of the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum was the son of Kore, a descendant of Abiasaph, from the clan of Korah. He and his relatives, the Korahites, were responsible for guarding the entrance to the sanctuary, just as their ancestors had guarded the Tabernacle in the camp of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Phinehas son of Eleazar had been in charge of the gatekeepers in earlier times, and the Lord had been with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And later Zechariah son of Meshelemiah was responsible for guarding the entrance to the Tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: In all, there were 212 gatekeepers in those days, and they were listed according to the genealogies in their villages. David and Samuel the seer had appointed their ancestors because they were reliable men.
speaker: Narrator

text: These gatekeepers and their descendants, by their divisions, were responsible for guarding the entrance to the house of the Lord when that house was a tent.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gatekeepers were stationed on all four sides—east, west, north, and south.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their relatives in the villages came regularly to share their duties for seven-day periods.
speaker: Narrator

text: The four chief gatekeepers, all Levites, were trusted officials, for they were responsible for the rooms and treasuries at the house of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: They would spend the night around the house of God, since it was their duty to guard it and to open the gates every morning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the gatekeepers were assigned to care for the various articles used in worship. They checked them in and out to avoid any loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: Others were responsible for the furnishings, the items in the sanctuary, and the supplies, such as choice flour, wine, olive oil, frankincense, and spices.
speaker: Narrator

text: But it was the priests who blended the spices.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mattithiah, a Levite and the oldest son of Shallum the Korahite, was entrusted with baking the bread used in the offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: And some members of the clan of Kohath were in charge of preparing the bread to be set on the table each Sabbath day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The musicians, all prominent Levites, lived at the Temple. They were exempt from other responsibilities since they were on duty at all hours.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these men lived in Jerusalem. They were the heads of Levite families and were listed as prominent leaders in their genealogical records.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeiel (the father of Gibeon) lived in the town of Gibeon. His wife’s name was Maacah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and his oldest son was named Abdon. Jeiel’s other sons were Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab,
speaker: Narrator

text: Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah, and Mikloth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mikloth was the father of Shimeam. All these families lived near each other in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ner was the father of Kish.
Kish was the father of Saul.
Saul was the father of Jonathan, Malkishua, Abinadab, and Esh-baal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jonathan was the father of Merib-baal.
Merib-baal was the father of Micah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Micah were Pithon, Melech, Tahrea, and Ahaz.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahaz was the father of Jadah.
Jadah was the father of Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri.
Zimri was the father of Moza.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Moza was the father of Binea.
Binea’s son was Rephaiah.
Rephaiah’s son was Eleasah.
Eleasah’s son was Azel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Azel had six sons, whose names were Azrikam, Bokeru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. These were the sons of Azel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Philistines attacked Israel, and the men of Israel fled before them. Many were slaughtered on the slopes of Mount Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines closed in on Saul and his sons, and they killed three of his sons—Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malkishua.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fighting grew very fierce around Saul, and the Philistine archers caught up with him and wounded him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Saul groaned to his armor bearer, “Take your sword and kill me before these pagan Philistines come to taunt and torture me.”
But his armor bearer was afraid and would not do it. So Saul took his own sword and fell on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: When his armor bearer realized that Saul was dead, he fell on his own sword and died.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul and his three sons died there together, bringing his dynasty to an end.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the Israelites in the Jezreel Valley saw that their army had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their towns and fled. So the Philistines moved in and occupied their towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day, when the Philistines went out to strip the dead, they found the bodies of Saul and his sons on Mount Gilboa.
speaker: Narrator

text: So they stripped off Saul’s armor and cut off his head. Then they proclaimed the good news of Saul’s death before their idols and to the people throughout the land of Philistia.
speaker: Narrator

text: They placed his armor in the temple of their gods, and they fastened his head to the temple of Dagon.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when everyone in Jabesh-gilead heard about everything the Philistines had done to Saul,
speaker: Narrator

text: all their mighty warriors brought the bodies of Saul and his sons back to Jabesh. Then they buried their bones beneath the great tree at Jabesh, and they fasted for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Saul died because he was unfaithful to the Lord. He failed to obey the Lord’s command, and he even consulted a medium
speaker: Narrator

text: instead of asking the Lord for guidance. So the Lord killed him and turned the kingdom over to David son of Jesse.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all Israel gathered before David at Hebron and told him, “We are your own flesh and blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the past, even when Saul was king, you were the one who really led the forces of Israel. And the Lord your God told you, ‘You will be the shepherd of my people Israel. You will be the leader of my people Israel.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So there at Hebron, David made a covenant before the Lord with all the elders of Israel. And they anointed him king of Israel, just as the Lord had promised through Samuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David and all Israel went to Jerusalem (or Jebus, as it used to be called), where the Jebusites, the original inhabitants of the land, were living.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people of Jebus taunted David, saying, “You’ll never get in here!” But David captured the fortress of Zion, which is now called the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David had said to his troops, “Whoever is first to attack the Jebusites will become the commander of my armies!” And Joab, the son of David’s sister Zeruiah, was first to attack, so he became the commander of David’s armies.
speaker: Narrator

text: David made the fortress his home, and that is why it is called the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: He extended the city from the supporting terraces to the surrounding area, while Joab rebuilt the rest of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And David became more and more powerful, because the Lord of Heaven’s Armies was with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the leaders of David’s mighty warriors. Together with all Israel, they decided to make David their king, just as the Lord had promised concerning Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is the record of David’s mightiest warriors: The first was Jashobeam the Hacmonite, who was leader of the Three—the mightiest warriors among David’s men. He once used his spear to kill 300 enemy warriors in a single battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Next in rank among the Three was Eleazar son of Dodai, a descendant of Ahoah.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was with David when the Philistines gathered for battle at Pas-dammim and attacked the Israelites in a field full of barley. The Israelite army fled,
speaker: Narrator

text: but Eleazar and David held their ground in the middle of the field and beat back the Philistines. So the Lord saved them by giving them a great victory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once when David was at the rock near the cave of Adullam, the Philistine army was camped in the valley of Rephaim. The Three (who were among the Thirty—an elite group among David’s fighting men) went down to meet him there.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was staying in the stronghold at the time, and a Philistine detachment had occupied the town of Bethlehem.
speaker: Narrator

text: David remarked longingly to his men, “Oh, how I would love some of that good water from the well by the gate in Bethlehem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Three broke through the Philistine lines, drew some water from the well by the gate in Bethlehem, and brought it back to David. But David refused to drink it. Instead, he poured it out as an offering to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “God forbid that I should drink this!” he exclaimed. “This water is as precious as the blood of these men who risked their lives to bring it to me.” So David did not drink it. These are examples of the exploits of the Three.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishai, the brother of Joab, was the leader of the Thirty. He once used his spear to kill 300 enemy warriors in a single battle. It was by such feats that he became as famous as the Three.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishai was the most famous of the Thirty and was their commander, though he was not one of the Three.
speaker: Narrator

text: There was also Benaiah son of Jehoiada, a valiant warrior from Kabzeel. He did many heroic deeds, which included killing two champions of Moab. Another time, on a snowy day, he chased a lion down into a pit and killed it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Once, armed only with a club, he killed an Egyptian warrior who was 7 1⁄2 feet tall and who was armed with a spear as thick as a weaver’s beam. Benaiah wrenched the spear from the Egyptian’s hand and killed him with it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Deeds like these made Benaiah as famous as the three mightiest warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was more honored than the other members of the Thirty, though he was not one of the Three. And David made him captain of his bodyguard.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Shammah from Harod;
Helez from Pelon;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ira son of Ikkesh from Tekoa;
Abiezer from Anathoth;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sibbecai from Hushah;
Zalmon from Ahoah;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Maharai from Netophah;
Heled son of Baanah from Netophah;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ithai son of Ribai from Gibeah (in the land of Benjamin);
Benaiah from Pirathon;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hurai from near Nahale-gaash;
Abi-albon from Arabah;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Azmaveth from Bahurim;
Eliahba from Shaalbon;
speaker: Narrator

text:
the sons of Jashen from Gizon;
Jonathan son of Shagee from Harar;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ahiam son of Sharar from Harar;
Eliphal son of Ur;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hepher from Mekerah;
Ahijah from Pelon;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hezro from Carmel;
Paarai son of Ezbai;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Joel, the brother of Nathan;
Mibhar son of Hagri;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Zelek from Ammon;
Naharai from Beeroth, the armor bearer of Joab son of Zeruiah;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ira from Jattir;
Gareb from Jattir;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Uriah the Hittite;
Zabad son of Ahlai;
speaker: Narrator

text: Adina son of Shiza, the Reubenite leader who had thirty men with him;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hanan son of Maacah;
Joshaphat from Mithna;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Uzzia from Ashtaroth;
Shama and Jeiel, the sons of Hotham, from Aroer;
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jediael son of Shimri;
Joha, his brother, from Tiz;
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Eliel and Obed;
Jaasiel from Zobah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following men joined David at Ziklag while he was hiding from Saul son of Kish. They were among the warriors who fought beside David in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of them were expert archers, and they could shoot arrows or sling stones with their left hand as well as their right. They were all relatives of Saul from the tribe of Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Ishmaiah from Gibeon, a famous warrior and leader among the Thirty;
Jeremiah, Jahaziel, Johanan, and Jozabad from Gederah;
speaker: Narrator

text: Eluzai, Jerimoth, Bealiah, Shemariah, and Shephatiah from Haruph;
speaker: Narrator

text: Elkanah, Isshiah, Azarel, Joezer, and Jashobeam, who were Korahites;
speaker: Narrator

text: Joelah and Zebadiah, sons of Jeroham from Gedor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some brave and experienced warriors from the tribe of Gad also defected to David while he was at the stronghold in the wilderness. They were expert with both shield and spear, as fierce as lions and as swift as deer on the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ezer was their leader.
Obadiah was second.
Eliab was third.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mishmannah was fourth.
Jeremiah was fifth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Attai was sixth.
Eliel was seventh.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Johanan was eighth.
Elzabad was ninth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jeremiah was tenth.
Macbannai was eleventh.
speaker: Narrator

text: These warriors from Gad were army commanders. The weakest among them could take on a hundred regular troops, and the strongest could take on a thousand!
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the men who crossed the Jordan River during its seasonal flooding at the beginning of the year and drove out all the people living in the lowlands on both the east and west banks.
speaker: Narrator

text: Others from Benjamin and Judah came to David at the stronghold.
speaker: Narrator

text: David went out to meet them and said, “If you have come in peace to help me, we are friends. But if you have come to betray me to my enemies when I am innocent, then may the God of our ancestors see it and punish you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Spirit came upon Amasai, the leader of the Thirty, and he said,
“We are yours, David!
    We are on your side, son of Jesse.
Peace and prosperity be with you,
    and success to all who help you,
    for your God is the one who helps you.”
So David let them join him, and he made them officers over his troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some men from Manasseh defected from the Israelite army and joined David when he set out with the Philistines to fight against Saul. But as it turned out, the Philistine rulers refused to let David and his men go with them. After much discussion, they sent them back, for they said, “It will cost us our heads if David switches loyalties to Saul and turns against us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Here is a list of the men from Manasseh who defected to David as he was returning to Ziklag: Adnah, Jozabad, Jediael, Michael, Jozabad, Elihu, and Zillethai. Each commanded 1,000 troops from the tribe of Manasseh.
speaker: Narrator

text: They helped David chase down bands of raiders, for they were all brave and able warriors who became commanders in his army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Day after day more men joined David until he had a great army, like the army of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the numbers of armed warriors who joined David at Hebron. They were all eager to see David become king instead of Saul, just as the Lord had promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Judah, there were 6,800 warriors armed with shields and spears.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Simeon, there were 7,100 brave warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Levi, there were 4,600 warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: This included Jehoiada, leader of the family of Aaron, who had 3,700 under his command.
speaker: Narrator

text: This also included Zadok, a brave young warrior, with 22 members of his family who were all officers.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Benjamin, Saul’s relatives, there were 3,000 warriors. Most of the men from Benjamin had remained loyal to Saul until this time.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Ephraim, there were 20,800 brave warriors, each highly respected in his own clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the half-tribe of Manasseh west of the Jordan, 18,000 men were designated by name to help David become king.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Issachar, there were 200 leaders of the tribe with their relatives. All these men understood the signs of the times and knew the best course for Israel to take.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Zebulun, there were 50,000 skilled warriors. They were fully armed and prepared for battle and completely loyal to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Naphtali, there were 1,000 officers and 37,000 warriors armed with shields and spears.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Dan, there were 28,600 warriors, all prepared for battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the tribe of Asher, there were 40,000 trained warriors, all prepared for battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the east side of the Jordan River—where the tribes of Reuben and Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh lived—there were 120,000 troops armed with every kind of weapon.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these men came in battle array to Hebron with the single purpose of making David the king over all Israel. In fact, everyone in Israel agreed that David should be their king.
speaker: Narrator

text: They feasted and drank with David for three days, for preparations had been made by their relatives for their arrival.
speaker: Narrator

text: And people from as far away as Issachar, Zebulun, and Naphtali brought food on donkeys, camels, mules, and oxen. Vast supplies of flour, fig cakes, clusters of raisins, wine, olive oil, cattle, sheep, and goats were brought to the celebration. There was great joy throughout the land of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David consulted with all his officials, including the generals and captains of his army.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he addressed the entire assembly of Israel as follows: “If you approve and if it is the will of the Lord our God, let us send messages to all the Israelites throughout the land, including the priests and Levites in their towns and pasturelands. Let us invite them to come and join us.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is time to bring back the Ark of our God, for we neglected it during the reign of Saul.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole assembly agreed to this, for the people could see it was the right thing to do.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David summoned all Israel, from the Shihor Brook of Egypt in the south all the way to the town of Lebo-hamath in the north, to join in bringing the Ark of God from Kiriath-jearim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David and all Israel went to Baalah of Judah (also called Kiriath-jearim) to bring back the Ark of God, which bears the name of the Lord who is enthroned between the cherubim.
speaker: Narrator

text: They placed the Ark of God on a new cart and brought it from Abinadab’s house. Uzzah and Ahio were guiding the cart.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and all Israel were celebrating before God with all their might, singing songs and playing all kinds of musical instruments—lyres, harps, tambourines, cymbals, and trumpets.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when they arrived at the threshing floor of Nacon, the oxen stumbled, and Uzzah reached out his hand to steady the Ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord’s anger was aroused against Uzzah, and he struck him dead because he had laid his hand on the Ark. So Uzzah died there in the presence of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was angry because the Lord’s anger had burst out against Uzzah. He named that place Perez-uzzah (which means “to burst out against Uzzah”), as it is still called today.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was now afraid of God, and he asked, “How can I ever bring the Ark of God back into my care?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David did not move the Ark into the City of David. Instead, he took it to the house of Obed-edom of Gath.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ark of God remained there in Obed-edom’s house for three months, and the Lord blessed the household of Obed-edom and everything he owned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King Hiram of Tyre sent messengers to David, along with cedar timber, and stonemasons and carpenters to build him a palace.
speaker: Narrator

text: And David realized that the Lord had confirmed him as king over Israel and had greatly blessed his kingdom for the sake of his people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David married more wives in Jerusalem, and they had more sons and daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the names of David’s sons who were born in Jerusalem: Shammua, Shobab, Nathan, Solomon,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ibhar, Elishua, Elpelet,
speaker: Narrator

text: Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia,
speaker: Narrator

text: Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Philistines heard that David had been anointed king over all Israel, they mobilized all their forces to capture him. But David was told they were coming, so he marched out to meet them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines arrived and made a raid in the valley of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
So David asked God, “Should I go out to fight the Philistines? Will you hand them over to me?”
The Lord replied, “Yes, go ahead. I will hand them over to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David and his troops went up to Baal-perazim and defeated the Philistines there. “God did it!” David exclaimed. “He used me to burst through my enemies like a raging flood!” So they named that place Baal-perazim (which means “the Lord who bursts through”).
speaker: Narrator

text: The Philistines had abandoned their gods there, so David gave orders to burn them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after a while the Philistines returned and raided the valley again.
speaker: Narrator

text: And once again David asked God what to do. “Do not attack them straight on,” God replied. “Instead, circle around behind and attack them near the poplar trees.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you hear a sound like marching feet in the tops of the poplar trees, go out and attack! That will be the signal that God is moving ahead of you to strike down the Philistine army.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David did what God commanded, and they struck down the Philistine army all the way from Gibeon to Gezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David’s fame spread everywhere, and the Lord caused all the nations to fear David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David now built several buildings for himself in the City of David. He also prepared a place for the Ark of God and set up a special tent for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he commanded, “No one except the Levites may carry the Ark of God. The Lord has chosen them to carry the Ark of the Lord and to serve him forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David summoned all Israel to Jerusalem to bring the Ark of the Lord to the place he had prepared for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the number of the descendants of Aaron (the priests) and the Levites who were called together:
speaker: Narrator

text: From the clan of Kohath, 120, with Uriel as their leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the clan of Merari, 220, with Asaiah as their leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the clan of Gershon, 130, with Joel as their leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Elizaphan, 200, with Shemaiah as their leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Hebron, 80, with Eliel as their leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Uzziel, 112, with Amminadab as their leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David summoned the priests, Zadok and Abiathar, and these Levite leaders: Uriel, Asaiah, Joel, Shemaiah, Eliel, and Amminadab.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “You are the leaders of the Levite families. You must purify yourselves and all your fellow Levites, so you can bring the Ark of the Lord, the God of Israel, to the place I have prepared for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because you Levites did not carry the Ark the first time, the anger of the Lord our God burst out against us. We failed to ask God how to move it properly.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the priests and the Levites purified themselves in order to bring the Ark of the Lord, the God of Israel, to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Levites carried the Ark of God on their shoulders with its carrying poles, just as the Lord had instructed Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also ordered the Levite leaders to appoint a choir of Levites who were singers and musicians to sing joyful songs to the accompaniment of harps, lyres, and cymbals.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Levites appointed Heman son of Joel along with his fellow Levites: Asaph son of Berekiah, and Ethan son of Kushaiah from the clan of Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following men were chosen as their assistants: Zechariah, Jaaziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Benaiah, Maaseiah, Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, and the gatekeepers—Obed-edom and Jeiel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The musicians Heman, Asaph, and Ethan were chosen to sound the bronze cymbals.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zechariah, Aziel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Unni, Eliab, Maaseiah, and Benaiah were chosen to play the harps.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mattithiah, Eliphelehu, Mikneiah, Obed-edom, Jeiel, and Azaziah were chosen to play the lyres.
speaker: Narrator

text: Kenaniah, the head Levite, was chosen as the choir leader because of his skill.
speaker: Narrator

text: Berekiah and Elkanah were chosen to guard the Ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shebaniah, Joshaphat, Nethanel, Amasai, Zechariah, Benaiah, and Eliezer—all of whom were priests—were chosen to blow the trumpets as they marched in front of the Ark of God. Obed-edom and Jehiah were chosen to guard the Ark.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David and the elders of Israel and the generals of the army went to the house of Obed-edom to bring the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant up to Jerusalem with a great celebration.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because God was clearly helping the Levites as they carried the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant, they sacrificed seven bulls and seven rams.
speaker: Narrator

text: David was dressed in a robe of fine linen, as were all the Levites who carried the Ark, and also the singers, and Kenaniah the choir leader. David was also wearing a priestly garment.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all Israel brought up the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant with shouts of joy, the blowing of rams’ horns and trumpets, the crashing of cymbals, and loud playing on harps and lyres.
speaker: Narrator

text: But as the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant entered the City of David, Michal, the daughter of Saul, looked down from her window. When she saw King David skipping about and laughing with joy, she was filled with contempt for him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought the Ark of God and placed it inside the special tent David had prepared for it. And they presented burnt offerings and peace offerings to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had finished his sacrifices, David blessed the people in the name of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he gave to every man and woman in all Israel a loaf of bread, a cake of dates, and a cake of raisins.
speaker: Narrator

text: David appointed the following Levites to lead the people in worship before the Ark of the Lord—to invoke his blessings, to give thanks, and to praise the Lord, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asaph, the leader of this group, sounded the cymbals. Second to him was Zechariah, followed by Jeiel, Shemiramoth, Jehiel, Mattithiah, Eliab, Benaiah, Obed-edom, and Jeiel. They played the harps and lyres.
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests, Benaiah and Jahaziel, played the trumpets regularly before the Ark of God’s Covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day David gave to Asaph and his fellow Levites this song of thanksgiving to the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give thanks to the Lord and proclaim his greatness.
    Let the whole world know what he has done.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sing to him; yes, sing his praises.
    Tell everyone about his wonderful deeds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Exult in his holy name;
    rejoice, you who worship the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Search for the Lord and for his strength;
    continually seek him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember the wonders he has performed,
    his miracles, and the rulings he has given,
speaker: Narrator

text:
you children of his servant Israel,
    you descendants of Jacob, his chosen ones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He is the Lord our God.
    His justice is seen throughout the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Remember his covenant forever—
    the commitment he made to a thousand generations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the covenant he made with Abraham
    and the oath he swore to Isaac.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He confirmed it to Jacob as a decree,
    and to the people of Israel as a never-ending covenant:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I will give you the land of Canaan
    as your special possession.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
He said this when you were few in number,
    a tiny group of strangers in Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They wandered from nation to nation,
    from one kingdom to another.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Yet he did not let anyone oppress them.
    He warned kings on their behalf:
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do not touch my chosen people,
    and do not hurt my prophets.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the whole earth sing to the Lord!
    Each day proclaim the good news that he saves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Publish his glorious deeds among the nations.
    Tell everyone about the amazing things he does.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Great is the Lord! He is most worthy of praise!
    He is to be feared above all gods.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The gods of other nations are mere idols,
    but the Lord made the heavens!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Honor and majesty surround him;
    strength and joy fill his dwelling.
speaker: Narrator

text:
O nations of the world, recognize the Lord,
    recognize that the Lord is glorious and strong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give to the Lord the glory he deserves!
    Bring your offering and come into his presence.
Worship the Lord in all his holy splendor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let all the earth tremble before him.
    The world stands firm and cannot be shaken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the heavens be glad, and the earth rejoice!
    Tell all the nations, “The Lord reigns!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the sea and everything in it shout his praise!
    Let the fields and their crops burst out with joy!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the trees of the forest sing for joy before the Lord,
    for he is coming to judge the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give thanks to the Lord, for he is good!
    His faithful love endures forever.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Cry out, “Save us, O God of our salvation!
    Gather and rescue us from among the nations,
so we can thank your holy name
    and rejoice and praise you.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Praise the Lord, the God of Israel,
    who lives from everlasting to everlasting!
And all the people shouted “Amen!” and praised the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: David arranged for Asaph and his fellow Levites to serve regularly before the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant, doing whatever needed to be done each day.
speaker: Narrator

text: This group included Obed-edom (son of Jeduthun), Hosah, and sixty-eight other Levites as gatekeepers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meanwhile, David stationed Zadok the priest and his fellow priests at the Tabernacle of the Lord at the place of worship in Gibeon, where they continued to minister before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They sacrificed the regular burnt offerings to the Lord each morning and evening on the altar set aside for that purpose, obeying everything written in the Law of the Lord, as he had commanded Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also appointed Heman, Jeduthun, and the others chosen by name to give thanks to the Lord, for “his faithful love endures forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They used their trumpets, cymbals, and other instruments to accompany their songs of praise to God. And the sons of Jeduthun were appointed as gatekeepers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all the people returned to their homes, and David turned and went home to bless his own family.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David was settled in his palace, he summoned Nathan the prophet. “Look,” David said, “I am living in a beautiful cedar palace, but the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant is out there under a tent!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Nathan replied to David, “Do whatever you have in mind, for God is with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But that same night God said to Nathan,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go and tell my servant David, ‘This is what the Lord has declared: You are not the one to build a house for me to live in.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have never lived in a house, from the day I brought the Israelites out of Egypt until this very day. My home has always been a tent, moving from one place to another in a Tabernacle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet no matter where I have gone with the Israelites, I have never once complained to Israel’s leaders, the shepherds of my people. I have never asked them, “Why haven’t you built me a beautiful cedar house?”’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now go and say to my servant David, ‘This is what the Lord of Heaven’s Armies has declared: I took you from tending sheep in the pasture and selected you to be the leader of my people Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have been with you wherever you have gone, and I have destroyed all your enemies before your eyes. Now I will make your name as famous as anyone who has ever lived on the earth!
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will provide a homeland for my people Israel, planting them in a secure place where they will never be disturbed. Evil nations won’t oppress them as they’ve done in the past,
speaker: Narrator

text:
starting from the time I appointed judges to rule my people Israel. And I will defeat all your enemies.
“‘Furthermore, I declare that the Lord will build a house for you—a dynasty of kings!
speaker: Narrator

text: For when you die and join your ancestors, I will raise up one of your descendants, one of your sons, and I will make his kingdom strong.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is the one who will build a house—a temple—for me. And I will secure his throne forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will be his father, and he will be my son. I will never take my favor from him as I took it from the one who ruled before you.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will confirm him as king over my house and my kingdom for all time, and his throne will be secure forever.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Nathan went back to David and told him everything the Lord had said in this vision.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then King David went in and sat before the Lord and prayed,
“Who am I, O Lord God, and what is my family, that you have brought me this far?
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, O God, in addition to everything else, you speak of giving your servant a lasting dynasty! You speak as though I were someone very great, O Lord God!
speaker: Narrator

text: “What more can I say to you about the way you have honored me? You know what your servant is really like.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the sake of your servant, O Lord, and according to your will, you have done all these great things and have made them known.
speaker: Narrator
