text: “O Lord, there is no one like you. We have never even heard of another God like you!
speaker: Narrator

text: What other nation on earth is like your people Israel? What other nation, O God, have you redeemed from slavery to be your own people? You made a great name for yourself when you redeemed your people from Egypt. You performed awesome miracles and drove out the nations that stood in their way.
speaker: Narrator

text: You chose Israel to be your very own people forever, and you, O Lord, became their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now, O Lord, I am your servant; do as you have promised concerning me and my family. May it be a promise that will last forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: And may your name be established and honored forever so that everyone will say, ‘The Lord of Heaven’s Armies, the God of Israel, is Israel’s God!’ And may the house of your servant David continue before you forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: “O my God, I have been bold enough to pray to you because you have revealed to your servant that you will build a house for him—a dynasty of kings!
speaker: Narrator

text: For you are God, O Lord. And you have promised these good things to your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, it has pleased you to bless the house of your servant, so that it will continue forever before you. For when you grant a blessing, O Lord, it is an eternal blessing!”
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, David defeated and subdued the Philistines by conquering Gath and its surrounding towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also conquered the land of Moab, and the Moabites who were spared became David’s subjects and paid him tribute money.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also destroyed the forces of Hadadezer, king of Zobah, as far as Hamath, when Hadadezer marched out to strengthen his control along the Euphrates River.
speaker: Narrator

text: David captured 1,000 chariots, 7,000 charioteers, and 20,000 foot soldiers. He crippled all the chariot horses except enough for 100 chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Arameans from Damascus arrived to help King Hadadezer, David killed 22,000 of them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he placed several army garrisons in Damascus, the Aramean capital, and the Arameans became David’s subjects and paid him tribute money. So the Lord made David victorious wherever he went.
speaker: Narrator

text: David brought the gold shields of Hadadezer’s officers to Jerusalem,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with a large amount of bronze from Hadadezer’s towns of Tebah and Cun. Later Solomon melted the bronze and molded it into the great bronze basin called the Sea, the pillars, and the various bronze articles used at the Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: When King Toi of Hamath heard that David had destroyed the entire army of King Hadadezer of Zobah,
speaker: Narrator

text: he sent his son Joram to congratulate King David for his successful campaign. Hadadezer and Toi had been enemies and were often at war. Joram presented David with many gifts of gold, silver, and bronze.
speaker: Narrator

text: King David dedicated all these gifts to the Lord, along with the silver and gold he had taken from the other nations—from Edom, Moab, Ammon, Philistia, and Amalek.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abishai son of Zeruiah destroyed 18,000 Edomites in the Valley of Salt.
speaker: Narrator

text: He placed army garrisons in Edom, and all the Edomites became David’s subjects. In fact, the Lord made David victorious wherever he went.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David reigned over all Israel and did what was just and right for all his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab son of Zeruiah was commander of the army. Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the royal historian.
speaker: Narrator

text: Zadok son of Ahitub and Ahimelech son of Abiathar were the priests. Seraiah was the court secretary.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada was captain of the king’s bodyguard. And David’s sons served as the king’s chief assistants.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some time after this, King Nahash of the Ammonites died, and his son Hanun became king.
speaker: Narrator

text:
David said, “I am going to show loyalty to Hanun because his father, Nahash, was always loyal to me.” So David sent messengers to express sympathy to Hanun about his father’s death.
But when David’s ambassadors arrived in the land of Ammon,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Ammonite commanders said to Hanun, “Do you really think these men are coming here to honor your father? No! David has sent them to spy out the land so they can come in and conquer it!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Hanun seized David’s ambassadors and shaved them, cut off their robes at the buttocks, and sent them back to David in shame.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David heard what had happened to the men, he sent messengers to tell them, “Stay at Jericho until your beards grow out, and then come back.” For they felt deep shame because of their appearance.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the people of Ammon realized how seriously they had angered David, Hanun and the Ammonites sent 75,000 pounds of silver to hire chariots and charioteers from Aram-naharaim, Aram-maacah, and Zobah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also hired 32,000 chariots and secured the support of the king of Maacah and his army. These forces camped at Medeba, where they were joined by the Ammonite troops that Hanun had recruited from his own towns.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David heard about this, he sent Joab and all his warriors to fight them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Ammonite troops came out and drew up their battle lines at the entrance of the city, while the other kings positioned themselves to fight in the open fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joab saw that he would have to fight on both the front and the rear, he chose some of Israel’s elite troops and placed them under his personal command to fight the Arameans in the fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: He left the rest of the army under the command of his brother Abishai, who was to attack the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If the Arameans are too strong for me, then come over and help me,” Joab told his brother. “And if the Ammonites are too strong for you, I will help you.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be courageous! Let us fight bravely for our people and the cities of our God. May the Lord’s will be done.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Joab and his troops attacked, the Arameans began to run away.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the Ammonites saw the Arameans running, they also ran from Abishai and retreated into the city. Then Joab returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Arameans now realized that they were no match for Israel, so they sent messengers and summoned additional Aramean troops from the other side of the Euphrates River. These troops were under the command of Shobach, the commander of Hadadezer’s forces.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David heard what was happening, he mobilized all Israel, crossed the Jordan River, and positioned his troops in battle formation. Then David engaged the Arameans in battle, and they fought against him.
speaker: Narrator

text: But again the Arameans fled from the Israelites. This time David’s forces killed 7,000 charioteers and 40,000 foot soldiers, including Shobach, the commander of their army.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Hadadezer’s allies saw that they had been defeated by Israel, they surrendered to David and became his subjects. After that, the Arameans were no longer willing to help the Ammonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the spring of the year, when kings normally go out to war, Joab led the Israelite army in successful attacks against the land of the Ammonites. In the process he laid siege to the city of Rabbah, attacking and destroying it. However, David stayed behind in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David went to Rabbah and removed the crown from the king’s head, and it was placed on his own head. The crown was made of gold and set with gems, and he found that it weighed seventy-five pounds. David took a vast amount of plunder from the city.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also made slaves of the people of Rabbah and forced them to labor with saws, iron picks, and iron axes. That is how David dealt with the people of all the Ammonite towns. Then David and all the army returned to Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: After this, war broke out with the Philistines at Gezer. As they fought, Sibbecai from Hushah killed Saph, a descendant of the giants, and so the Philistines were subdued.
speaker: Narrator

text: During another battle with the Philistines, Elhanan son of Jair killed Lahmi, the brother of Goliath of Gath. The handle of Lahmi’s spear was as thick as a weaver’s beam!
speaker: Narrator

text: In another battle with the Philistines at Gath, they encountered a huge man with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot, twenty-four in all, who was also a descendant of the giants.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when he defied and taunted Israel, he was killed by Jonathan, the son of David’s brother Shimea.
speaker: Narrator

text: These Philistines were descendants of the giants of Gath, but David and his warriors killed them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Satan rose up against Israel and caused David to take a census of the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David said to Joab and the commanders of the army, “Take a census of all the people of Israel—from Beersheba in the south to Dan in the north—and bring me a report so I may know how many there are.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joab replied, “May the Lord increase the number of his people a hundred times over! But why, my lord the king, do you want to do this? Are they not all your servants? Why must you cause Israel to sin?”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the king insisted that they take the census, so Joab traveled throughout all Israel to count the people. Then he returned to Jerusalem
speaker: Narrator

text: and reported the number of people to David. There were 1,100,000 warriors in all Israel who could handle a sword, and 470,000 in Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Joab did not include the tribes of Levi and Benjamin in the census because he was so distressed at what the king had made him do.
speaker: Narrator

text: God was very displeased with the census, and he punished Israel for it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to God, “I have sinned greatly by taking this census. Please forgive my guilt for doing this foolish thing.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Gad, David’s seer. This was the message:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Go and say to David, ‘This is what the Lord says: I will give you three choices. Choose one of these punishments, and I will inflict it on you.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Gad came to David and said, “These are the choices the Lord has given you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You may choose three years of famine, three months of destruction by the sword of your enemies, or three days of severe plague as the angel of the Lord brings devastation throughout the land of Israel. Decide what answer I should give the Lord who sent me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “I’m in a desperate situation!” David replied to Gad. “But let me fall into the hands of the Lord, for his mercy is very great. Do not let me fall into human hands.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord sent a plague upon Israel, and 70,000 people died as a result.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God sent an angel to destroy Jerusalem. But just as the angel was preparing to destroy it, the Lord relented and said to the death angel, “Stop! That is enough!” At that moment the angel of the Lord was standing by the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: David looked up and saw the angel of the Lord standing between heaven and earth with his sword drawn, reaching out over Jerusalem. So David and the leaders of Israel put on burlap to show their deep distress and fell face down on the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: And David said to God, “I am the one who called for the census! I am the one who has sinned and done wrong! But these people are as innocent as sheep—what have they done? O Lord my God, let your anger fall against me and my family, but do not destroy your people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord told Gad to instruct David to go up and build an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David went up to do what the Lord had commanded him through Gad.
speaker: Narrator

text: Araunah, who was busy threshing wheat at the time, turned and saw the angel there. His four sons, who were with him, ran away and hid.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Araunah saw David approaching, he left his threshing floor and bowed before David with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said to Araunah, “Let me buy this threshing floor from you at its full price. Then I will build an altar to the Lord there, so that he will stop the plague.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take it, my lord the king, and use it as you wish,” Araunah said to David. “I will give the oxen for the burnt offerings, and the threshing boards for wood to build a fire on the altar, and the wheat for the grain offering. I will give it all to you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But King David replied to Araunah, “No, I insist on buying it for the full price. I will not take what is yours and give it to the Lord. I will not present burnt offerings that have cost me nothing!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David gave Araunah 600 pieces of gold in payment for the threshing floor.
speaker: Narrator

text: David built an altar there to the Lord and sacrificed burnt offerings and peace offerings. And when David prayed, the Lord answered him by sending fire from heaven to burn up the offering on the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to the angel, who put the sword back into its sheath.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David saw that the Lord had answered his prayer, he offered sacrifices there at Araunah’s threshing floor.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time the Tabernacle of the Lord and the altar of burnt offering that Moses had made in the wilderness were located at the place of worship in Gibeon.
speaker: Narrator

text: But David was not able to go there to inquire of God, because he was terrified by the drawn sword of the angel of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said, “This will be the location for the Temple of the Lord God and the place of the altar for Israel’s burnt offerings!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So David gave orders to call together the foreigners living in Israel, and he assigned them the task of preparing finished stone for building the Temple of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: David provided large amounts of iron for the nails that would be needed for the doors in the gates and for the clamps, and he gave more bronze than could be weighed.
speaker: Narrator

text: He also provided innumerable cedar logs, for the men of Tyre and Sidon had brought vast amounts of cedar to David.
speaker: Narrator

text: David said, “My son Solomon is still young and inexperienced. And since the Temple to be built for the Lord must be a magnificent structure, famous and glorious throughout the world, I will begin making preparations for it now.” So David collected vast amounts of building materials before his death.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David sent for his son Solomon and instructed him to build a Temple for the Lord, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “My son, I wanted to build a Temple to honor the name of the Lord my God,” David told him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But the Lord said to me, ‘You have killed many men in the battles you have fought. And since you have shed so much blood in my sight, you will not be the one to build a Temple to honor my name.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you will have a son who will be a man of peace. I will give him peace with his enemies in all the surrounding lands. His name will be Solomon, and I will give peace and quiet to Israel during his reign.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is the one who will build a Temple to honor my name. He will be my son, and I will be his father. And I will secure the throne of his kingdom over Israel forever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now, my son, may the Lord be with you and give you success as you follow his directions in building the Temple of the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: And may the Lord give you wisdom and understanding, that you may obey the Law of the Lord your God as you rule over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you will be successful if you carefully obey the decrees and regulations that the Lord gave to Israel through Moses. Be strong and courageous; do not be afraid or lose heart!
speaker: Narrator

text: “I have worked hard to provide materials for building the Temple of the Lord—nearly 4,000 tons of gold, 40,000 tons of silver, and so much iron and bronze that it cannot be weighed. I have also gathered timber and stone for the walls, though you may need to add more.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have a large number of skilled stonemasons and carpenters and craftsmen of every kind.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have expert goldsmiths and silversmiths and workers of bronze and iron. Now begin the work, and may the Lord be with you!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David ordered all the leaders of Israel to assist Solomon in this project.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The Lord your God is with you,” he declared. “He has given you peace with the surrounding nations. He has handed them over to me, and they are now subject to the Lord and his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now seek the Lord your God with all your heart and soul. Build the sanctuary of the Lord God so that you can bring the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant and the holy vessels of God into the Temple built to honor the Lord’s name.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When David was an old man, he appointed his son Solomon to be king over Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: David summoned all the leaders of Israel, together with the priests and Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Levites who were thirty years old or older were counted, and the total came to 38,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said, “From all the Levites, 24,000 will supervise the work at the Temple of the Lord. Another 6,000 will serve as officials and judges.
speaker: Narrator

text: Another 4,000 will work as gatekeepers, and 4,000 will praise the Lord with the musical instruments I have made.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David divided the Levites into divisions named after the clans descended from the three sons of Levi—Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gershonite family units were defined by their lines of descent from Libni and Shimei, the sons of Gershon.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three of the descendants of Libni were Jehiel (the family leader), Zetham, and Joel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the leaders of the family of Libni.
Three of the descendants of Shimei were Shelomoth, Haziel, and Haran.
speaker: Narrator

text: Four other descendants of Shimei were Jahath, Ziza, Jeush, and Beriah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jahath was the family leader, and Ziza was next. Jeush and Beriah were counted as a single family because neither had many sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Four of the descendants of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Amram were Aaron and Moses. Aaron and his descendants were set apart to dedicate the most holy things, to offer sacrifices in the Lord’s presence, to serve the Lord, and to pronounce blessings in his name forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for Moses, the man of God, his sons were included with the tribe of Levi.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Moses were Gershom and Eliezer.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Gershom included Shebuel, the family leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliezer had only one son, Rehabiah, the family leader. Rehabiah had numerous descendants.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Izhar included Shelomith, the family leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Hebron included Jeriah (the family leader), Amariah (the second), Jahaziel (the third), and Jekameam (the fourth).
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Uzziel included Micah (the family leader) and Isshiah (the second).
speaker: Narrator

text:
The descendants of Merari included Mahli and Mushi.
The sons of Mahli were Eleazar and Kish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleazar died with no sons, only daughters. His daughters married their cousins, the sons of Kish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Three of the descendants of Mushi were Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the descendants of Levi by clans, the leaders of their family groups, registered carefully by name. Each had to be twenty years old or older to qualify for service in the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: For David said, “The Lord, the God of Israel, has given us peace, and he will always live in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the Levites will no longer need to carry the Tabernacle and its furnishings from place to place.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In accordance with David’s final instructions, all the Levites twenty years old or older were registered for service.
speaker: Narrator

text: The work of the Levites was to assist the priests, the descendants of Aaron, as they served at the house of the Lord. They also took care of the courtyards and side rooms, helped perform the ceremonies of purification, and served in many other ways in the house of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were in charge of the sacred bread that was set out on the table, the choice flour for the grain offerings, the wafers made without yeast, the cakes cooked in olive oil, and the other mixed breads. They were also responsible to check all the weights and measures.
speaker: Narrator

text: And each morning and evening they stood before the Lord to sing songs of thanks and praise to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: They assisted with the burnt offerings that were presented to the Lord on Sabbath days, at new moon celebrations, and at all the appointed festivals. The required number of Levites served in the Lord’s presence at all times, following all the procedures they had been given.
speaker: Narrator

text: And so, under the supervision of the priests, the Levites watched over the Tabernacle and the Temple and faithfully carried out their duties of service at the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is how Aaron’s descendants, the priests, were divided into groups for service. The sons of Aaron were Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nadab and Abihu died before their father, and they had no sons. So only Eleazar and Ithamar were left to carry on as priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: With the help of Zadok, who was a descendant of Eleazar, and of Ahimelech, who was a descendant of Ithamar, David divided Aaron’s descendants into groups according to their various duties.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleazar’s descendants were divided into sixteen groups and Ithamar’s into eight, for there were more family leaders among the descendants of Eleazar.
speaker: Narrator

text: All tasks were assigned to the various groups by means of sacred lots so that no preference would be shown, for there were many qualified officials serving God in the sanctuary from among the descendants of both Eleazar and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shemaiah son of Nethanel, a Levite, acted as secretary and wrote down the names and assignments in the presence of the king, the officials, Zadok the priest, Ahimelech son of Abiathar, and the family leaders of the priests and Levites. The descendants of Eleazar and Ithamar took turns casting lots.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The first lot fell to Jehoiarib.
The second lot fell to Jedaiah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The third lot fell to Harim.
The fourth lot fell to Seorim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fifth lot fell to Malkijah.
The sixth lot fell to Mijamin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The seventh lot fell to Hakkoz.
The eighth lot fell to Abijah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The ninth lot fell to Jeshua.
The tenth lot fell to Shecaniah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eleventh lot fell to Eliashib.
The twelfth lot fell to Jakim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The thirteenth lot fell to Huppah.
The fourteenth lot fell to Jeshebeab.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fifteenth lot fell to Bilgah.
The sixteenth lot fell to Immer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The seventeenth lot fell to Hezir.
The eighteenth lot fell to Happizzez.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The nineteenth lot fell to Pethahiah.
The twentieth lot fell to Jehezkel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The twenty-first lot fell to Jakin.
The twenty-second lot fell to Gamul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The twenty-third lot fell to Delaiah.
The twenty-fourth lot fell to Maaziah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Each group carried out its appointed duties in the house of the Lord according to the procedures established by their ancestor Aaron in obedience to the commands of the Lord, the God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These were the other family leaders descended from Levi:
From the descendants of Amram, the leader was Shebuel.
From the descendants of Shebuel, the leader was Jehdeiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Rehabiah, the leader was Isshiah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Izhar, the leader was Shelomith.
From the descendants of Shelomith, the leader was Jahath.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Hebron, Jeriah was the leader, Amariah was second, Jahaziel was third, and Jekameam was fourth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Uzziel, the leader was Micah.
From the descendants of Micah, the leader was Shamir,
speaker: Narrator

text:
along with Isshiah, the brother of Micah.
From the descendants of Isshiah, the leader was Zechariah.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Merari, the leaders were Mahli and Mushi.
From the descendants of Jaaziah, the leader was Beno.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Merari through Jaaziah, the leaders were Beno, Shoham, Zaccur, and Ibri.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Mahli, the leader was Eleazar, though he had no sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the descendants of Kish, the leader was Jerahmeel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the descendants of Mushi, the leaders were Mahli, Eder, and Jerimoth.
These were the descendants of Levi in their various families.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like the descendants of Aaron, they were assigned to their duties by means of sacred lots, without regard to age or rank. Lots were drawn in the presence of King David, Zadok, Ahimelech, and the family leaders of the priests and the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: David and the army commanders then appointed men from the families of Asaph, Heman, and Jeduthun to proclaim God’s messages to the accompaniment of lyres, harps, and cymbals. Here is a list of their names and their work:
speaker: Narrator

text: From the sons of Asaph, there were Zaccur, Joseph, Nethaniah, and Asarelah. They worked under the direction of their father, Asaph, who proclaimed God’s messages by the king’s orders.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the sons of Jeduthun, there were Gedaliah, Zeri, Jeshaiah, Shimei, Hashabiah, and Mattithiah, six in all. They worked under the direction of their father, Jeduthun, who proclaimed God’s messages to the accompaniment of the lyre, offering thanks and praise to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the sons of Heman, there were Bukkiah, Mattaniah, Uzziel, Shubael, Jerimoth, Hananiah, Hanani, Eliathah, Giddalti, Romamti-ezer, Joshbekashah, Mallothi, Hothir, and Mahazioth.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these were the sons of Heman, the king’s seer, for God had honored him with fourteen sons and three daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: All these men were under the direction of their fathers as they made music at the house of the Lord. Their responsibilities included the playing of cymbals, harps, and lyres at the house of God. Asaph, Jeduthun, and Heman reported directly to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: They and their families were all trained in making music before the Lord, and each of them—288 in all—was an accomplished musician.
speaker: Narrator

text: The musicians were appointed to their term of service by means of sacred lots, without regard to whether they were young or old, teacher or student.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The first lot fell to Joseph of the Asaph clan and twelve of his sons and relatives.
The second lot fell to Gedaliah and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The third lot fell to Zaccur and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fourth lot fell to Zeri and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifth lot fell to Nethaniah and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sixth lot fell to Bukkiah and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seventh lot fell to Asarelah and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eighth lot fell to Jeshaiah and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ninth lot fell to Mattaniah and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The tenth lot fell to Shimei and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eleventh lot fell to Uzziel and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twelfth lot fell to Hashabiah and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The thirteenth lot fell to Shubael and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fourteenth lot fell to Mattithiah and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifteenth lot fell to Jerimoth and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sixteenth lot fell to Hananiah and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The seventeenth lot fell to Joshbekashah and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The eighteenth lot fell to Hanani and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The nineteenth lot fell to Mallothi and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twentieth lot fell to Eliathah and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twenty-first lot fell to Hothir and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twenty-second lot fell to Giddalti and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twenty-third lot fell to Mahazioth and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text: The twenty-fourth lot fell to Romamti-ezer and twelve of his sons and relatives.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the divisions of the gatekeepers:
From the Korahites, there was Meshelemiah son of Kore, of the family of Abiasaph.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Meshelemiah were Zechariah (the oldest), Jediael (the second), Zebadiah (the third), Jathniel (the fourth),
speaker: Narrator

text: Elam (the fifth), Jehohanan (the sixth), and Eliehoenai (the seventh).
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Obed-edom, also gatekeepers, were Shemaiah (the oldest), Jehozabad (the second), Joah (the third), Sacar (the fourth), Nethanel (the fifth),
speaker: Narrator

text: Ammiel (the sixth), Issachar (the seventh), and Peullethai (the eighth). God had richly blessed Obed-edom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Obed-edom’s son Shemaiah had sons with great ability who earned positions of great authority in the clan.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their names were Othni, Rephael, Obed, and Elzabad. Their relatives, Elihu and Semakiah, were also very capable men.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of these descendants of Obed-edom, including their sons and grandsons—sixty-two of them in all—were very capable men, well qualified for their work.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meshelemiah’s eighteen sons and relatives were also very capable men.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hosah, of the Merari clan, appointed Shimri as the leader among his sons, though he was not the oldest.
speaker: Narrator

text: His other sons included Hilkiah (the second), Tebaliah (the third), and Zechariah (the fourth). Hosah’s sons and relatives, who served as gatekeepers, numbered thirteen in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: These divisions of the gatekeepers were named for their family leaders, and like the other Levites, they served at the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were assigned by families for guard duty at the various gates, without regard to age or training, for it was all decided by means of sacred lots.
speaker: Narrator

text: The responsibility for the east gate went to Meshelemiah and his group. The north gate was assigned to his son Zechariah, a man of unusual wisdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: The south gate went to Obed-edom, and his sons were put in charge of the storehouse.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shuppim and Hosah were assigned the west gate and the gateway leading up to the Temple. Guard duties were divided evenly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six Levites were assigned each day to the east gate, four to the north gate, four to the south gate, and two pairs at the storehouse.
speaker: Narrator

text: Six were assigned each day to the west gate, four to the gateway leading up to the Temple, and two to the courtyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the divisions of the gatekeepers from the clans of Korah and Merari.
speaker: Narrator

text: Other Levites, led by Ahijah, were in charge of the treasuries of the house of God and the treasuries of the gifts dedicated to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the family of Libni in the clan of Gershon, Jehiel was the leader.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Jehiel, Zetham and his brother Joel, were in charge of the treasuries of the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the leaders that descended from Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel:
speaker: Narrator

text: From the clan of Amram, Shebuel was a descendant of Gershom son of Moses. He was the chief officer of the treasuries.
speaker: Narrator

text: His relatives through Eliezer were Rehabiah, Jeshaiah, Joram, Zicri, and Shelomoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelomoth and his relatives were in charge of the treasuries containing the gifts that King David, the family leaders, and the generals and captains and other officers of the army had dedicated to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: These men dedicated some of the plunder they had gained in battle to maintain the house of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shelomoth and his relatives also cared for the gifts dedicated to the Lord by Samuel the seer, Saul son of Kish, Abner son of Ner, and Joab son of Zeruiah. All the other dedicated gifts were in their care, too.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the clan of Izhar came Kenaniah. He and his sons were given administrative responsibilities over Israel as officials and judges.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the clan of Hebron came Hashabiah. He and his relatives—1,700 capable men—were put in charge of the Israelite lands west of the Jordan River. They were responsible for all matters related to the things of the Lord and the service of the king in that area.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also from the clan of Hebron came Jeriah, who was the leader of the Hebronites according to the genealogical records. (In the fortieth year of David’s reign, a search was made in the records, and capable men from the clan of Hebron were found at Jazer in the land of Gilead.)
speaker: Narrator

text: There were 2,700 capable men among the relatives of Jeriah. King David sent them to the east side of the Jordan River and put them in charge of the tribes of Reuben and Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh. They were responsible for all matters related to God and to the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the list of Israelite generals and captains, and their officers, who served the king by supervising the army divisions that were on duty each month of the year. Each division served for one month and had 24,000 troops.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jashobeam son of Zabdiel was commander of the first division of 24,000 troops, which was on duty during the first month.
speaker: Narrator

text: He was a descendant of Perez and was in charge of all the army officers for the first month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Dodai, a descendant of Ahoah, was commander of the second division of 24,000 troops, which was on duty during the second month. Mikloth was his chief officer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah son of Jehoiada the priest was commander of the third division of 24,000 troops, which was on duty during the third month.
speaker: Narrator

text: This was the Benaiah who commanded David’s elite military group known as the Thirty. His son Ammizabad was his chief officer.
speaker: Narrator

text: Asahel, the brother of Joab, was commander of the fourth division of 24,000 troops, which was on duty during the fourth month. Asahel was succeeded by his son Zebadiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shammah the Izrahite was commander of the fifth division of 24,000 troops, which was on duty during the fifth month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ira son of Ikkesh from Tekoa was commander of the sixth division of 24,000 troops, which was on duty during the sixth month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Helez, a descendant of Ephraim from Pelon, was commander of the seventh division of 24,000 troops, which was on duty during the seventh month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sibbecai, a descendant of Zerah from Hushah, was commander of the eighth division of 24,000 troops, which was on duty during the eighth month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Abiezer from Anathoth in the territory of Benjamin was commander of the ninth division of 24,000 troops, which was on duty during the ninth month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Maharai, a descendant of Zerah from Netophah, was commander of the tenth division of 24,000 troops, which was on duty during the tenth month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Benaiah from Pirathon in Ephraim was commander of the eleventh division of 24,000 troops, which was on duty during the eleventh month.
speaker: Narrator

text: Heled, a descendant of Othniel from Netophah, was commander of the twelfth division of 24,000 troops, which was on duty during the twelfth month.
speaker: Narrator

text: The following were the tribes of Israel and their leaders:TribeLeaderReuben Eliezer son of ZicriSimeon Shephatiah son of Maacah
speaker: Narrator

text: Levi Hashabiah son of KemuelAaron (the priests) Zadok
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah Elihu (a brother of David)Issachar Omri son of Michael
speaker: Narrator

text: Zebulun Ishmaiah son of ObadiahNaphtali Jeremoth son of Azriel
speaker: Narrator

text: Ephraim Hoshea son of AzaziahManasseh (west) Joel son of Pedaiah
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh in Gilead (east) Iddo son of ZechariahBenjamin Jaasiel son of Abner
speaker: Narrator

text:
Dan Azarel son of Jeroham
These were the leaders of the tribes of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: When David took his census, he did not count those who were younger than twenty years of age, because the Lord had promised to make the Israelites as numerous as the stars in heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joab son of Zeruiah began the census but never finished it because the anger of God fell on Israel. The total number was never recorded in King David’s official records.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Azmaveth son of Adiel was in charge of the palace treasuries.
Jonathan son of Uzziah was in charge of the regional treasuries throughout the towns, villages, and fortresses of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ezri son of Kelub was in charge of the field workers who farmed the king’s lands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shimei from Ramah was in charge of the king’s vineyards.
Zabdi from Shepham was responsible for the grapes and the supplies of wine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Baal-hanan from Geder was in charge of the king’s olive groves and sycamore-fig trees in the foothills of Judah.
Joash was responsible for the supplies of olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shitrai from Sharon was in charge of the cattle on the Sharon Plain.
Shaphat son of Adlai was responsible for the cattle in the valleys.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Obil the Ishmaelite was in charge of the camels.
Jehdeiah from Meronoth was in charge of the donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Jaziz the Hagrite was in charge of the king’s flocks of sheep and goats.
All these officials were overseers of King David’s property.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jonathan, David’s uncle, was a wise counselor to the king, a man of great insight, and a scribe. Jehiel the Hacmonite was responsible for teaching the king’s sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahithophel was the royal adviser. Hushai the Arkite was the king’s friend.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahithophel was succeeded by Jehoiada son of Benaiah and by Abiathar. Joab was commander of the king’s army.
speaker: Narrator

text: David summoned all the officials of Israel to Jerusalem—the leaders of the tribes, the commanders of the army divisions, the other generals and captains, the overseers of the royal property and livestock, the palace officials, the mighty men, and all the other brave warriors in the kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: David rose to his feet and said: “My brothers and my people! It was my desire to build a Temple where the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant, God’s footstool, could rest permanently. I made the necessary preparations for building it,
speaker: Narrator

text: but God said to me, ‘You must not build a Temple to honor my name, for you are a warrior and have shed much blood.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Yet the Lord, the God of Israel, has chosen me from among all my father’s family to be king over Israel forever. For he has chosen the tribe of Judah to rule, and from among the families of Judah he chose my father’s family. And from among my father’s sons the Lord was pleased to make me king over all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from among my sons—for the Lord has given me many—he chose Solomon to succeed me on the throne of Israel and to rule over the Lord’s kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to me, ‘Your son Solomon will build my Temple and its courtyards, for I have chosen him as my son, and I will be his father.
speaker: Narrator

text: And if he continues to obey my commands and regulations as he does now, I will make his kingdom last forever.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “So now, with God as our witness, and in the sight of all Israel—the Lord’s assembly—I give you this charge. Be careful to obey all the commands of the Lord your God, so that you may continue to possess this good land and leave it to your children as a permanent inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And Solomon, my son, learn to know the God of your ancestors intimately. Worship and serve him with your whole heart and a willing mind. For the Lord sees every heart and knows every plan and thought. If you seek him, you will find him. But if you forsake him, he will reject you forever.
speaker: Narrator

text: So take this seriously. The Lord has chosen you to build a Temple as his sanctuary. Be strong, and do the work.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David gave Solomon the plans for the Temple and its surroundings, including the entry room, the storerooms, the upstairs rooms, the inner rooms, and the inner sanctuary—which was the place of atonement.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also gave Solomon all the plans he had in mind for the courtyards of the Lord’s Temple, the outside rooms, the treasuries, and the rooms for the gifts dedicated to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The king also gave Solomon the instructions concerning the work of the various divisions of priests and Levites in the Temple of the Lord. And he gave specifications for the items in the Temple that were to be used for worship.
speaker: Narrator

text: David gave instructions regarding how much gold and silver should be used to make the items needed for service.
speaker: Narrator

text: He told Solomon the amount of gold needed for the gold lampstands and lamps, and the amount of silver for the silver lampstands and lamps, depending on how each would be used.
speaker: Narrator

text: He designated the amount of gold for the table on which the Bread of the Presence would be placed and the amount of silver for other tables.
speaker: Narrator

text: David also designated the amount of gold for the solid gold meat hooks used to handle the sacrificial meat and for the basins, pitchers, and dishes, as well as the amount of silver for every dish.
speaker: Narrator

text: He designated the amount of refined gold for the altar of incense. Finally, he gave him a plan for the Lord’s “chariot”—the gold cherubim whose wings were stretched out over the Ark of the Lord’s Covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Every part of this plan,” David told Solomon, “was given to me in writing from the hand of the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David continued, “Be strong and courageous, and do the work. Don’t be afraid or discouraged, for the Lord God, my God, is with you. He will not fail you or forsake you. He will see to it that all the work related to the Temple of the Lord is finished correctly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The various divisions of priests and Levites will serve in the Temple of God. Others with skills of every kind will volunteer, and the officials and the entire nation are at your command.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then King David turned to the entire assembly and said, “My son Solomon, whom God has clearly chosen as the next king of Israel, is still young and inexperienced. The work ahead of him is enormous, for the Temple he will build is not for mere mortals—it is for the Lord God himself!
speaker: Narrator

text: Using every resource at my command, I have gathered as much as I could for building the Temple of my God. Now there is enough gold, silver, bronze, iron, and wood, as well as great quantities of onyx, other precious stones, costly jewels, and all kinds of fine stone and marble.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now, because of my devotion to the Temple of my God, I am giving all of my own private treasures of gold and silver to help in the construction. This is in addition to the building materials I have already collected for his holy Temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am donating more than 112 tons of gold from Ophir and 262 tons of refined silver to be used for overlaying the walls of the buildings
speaker: Narrator

text: and for the other gold and silver work to be done by the craftsmen. Now then, who will follow my example and give offerings to the Lord today?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the family leaders, the leaders of the tribes of Israel, the generals and captains of the army, and the king’s administrative officers all gave willingly.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the construction of the Temple of God, they gave about 188 tons of gold, 10,000 gold coins, 375 tons of silver, 675 tons of bronze, and 3,750 tons of iron.
speaker: Narrator

text: They also contributed numerous precious stones, which were deposited in the treasury of the house of the Lord under the care of Jehiel, a descendant of Gershon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people rejoiced over the offerings, for they had given freely and wholeheartedly to the Lord, and King David was filled with joy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then David praised the Lord in the presence of the whole assembly:
“O Lord, the God of our ancestor Israel, may you be praised forever and ever!
speaker: Narrator

text: Yours, O Lord, is the greatness, the power, the glory, the victory, and the majesty. Everything in the heavens and on earth is yours, O Lord, and this is your kingdom. We adore you as the one who is over all things.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wealth and honor come from you alone, for you rule over everything. Power and might are in your hand, and at your discretion people are made great and given strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: “O our God, we thank you and praise your glorious name!
speaker: Narrator

text: But who am I, and who are my people, that we could give anything to you? Everything we have has come from you, and we give you only what you first gave us!
speaker: Narrator

text: We are here for only a moment, visitors and strangers in the land as our ancestors were before us. Our days on earth are like a passing shadow, gone so soon without a trace.
speaker: Narrator

text: “O Lord our God, even this material we have gathered to build a Temple to honor your holy name comes from you! It all belongs to you!
speaker: Narrator

text: I know, my God, that you examine our hearts and rejoice when you find integrity there. You know I have done all this with good motives, and I have watched your people offer their gifts willingly and joyously.
speaker: Narrator

text: “O Lord, the God of our ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, make your people always want to obey you. See to it that their love for you never changes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Give my son Solomon the wholehearted desire to obey all your commands, laws, and decrees, and to do everything necessary to build this Temple, for which I have made these preparations.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then David said to the whole assembly, “Give praise to the Lord your God!” And the entire assembly praised the Lord, the God of their ancestors, and they bowed low and knelt before the Lord and the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: The next day they brought 1,000 bulls, 1,000 rams, and 1,000 male lambs as burnt offerings to the Lord. They also brought liquid offerings and many other sacrifices on behalf of all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They feasted and drank in the Lord’s presence with great joy that day.
And again they crowned David’s son Solomon as their new king. They anointed him before the Lord as their leader, and they anointed Zadok as priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Solomon took the throne of the Lord in place of his father, David, and he succeeded in everything, and all Israel obeyed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the officials, the warriors, and the sons of King David pledged their loyalty to King Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord exalted Solomon in the sight of all Israel, and he gave Solomon greater royal splendor than any king in Israel before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So David son of Jesse reigned over all Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: He reigned over Israel for forty years, seven of them in Hebron and thirty-three in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: He died at a ripe old age, having enjoyed long life, wealth, and honor. Then his son Solomon ruled in his place.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the events of King David’s reign, from beginning to end, are written in The Record of Samuel the Seer, The Record of Nathan the Prophet, and The Record of Gad the Seer.
speaker: Narrator

text: These accounts include the mighty deeds of his reign and everything that happened to him and to Israel and to all the surrounding kingdoms.
speaker: Narrator
